title: 111_hr3901
content: The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" is the short title of the Act. It includes provisions to enhance the administration of the first-time homebuyer tax credit. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends the age limitation for the tax credit, requiring taxpayers to be at least 18 years old at the time of purchasing a residence. Married taxpayers can meet this requirement if either spouse is of the required age. Additionally, documentation requirements are specified in the Act. The "Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009" amends documentation requirements for the tax credit, including a new requirement to attach a properly executed copy of the settlement statement to the tax return. Married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse are also subject to restrictions. Additionally, errors related to the First-Time Homebuyer Tax Credit are treated as mathematical or clerical errors. The First-Time Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009 amends documentation requirements for the tax credit and treats errors related to the credit as mathematical or clerical errors. New requirements include attaching a settlement statement to the tax return and restrictions for married individuals acquiring a residence from the family of their spouse. The amendments made by the First-Time Homebuyer Tax Credit Improvement Act of 2009 include new documentation requirements for the tax credit, effective for purchases after the enactment date. Failure to meet these requirements may result in ineligibility for the credit. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to returns for taxable years after the enactment of the Act, while the amendments made by subsection (d) apply to returns for taxable years after April 9, 2008. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Certain tax return preparers are required to file returns electronically. Subsection (e) of section 6011 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to require individual income tax returns prepared by tax return preparers to be filed on magnetic media if certain conditions are met. The term 'specified tax return preparer' refers to any tax preparer who expects to file more than 100 individual income tax returns in a calendar year. An individual income tax return is defined as any return of tax on individuals, estates, or trusts. A conforming amendment states that the Secretary may not require electronic filing, except in certain cases. These amendments apply to returns filed after December 31, 2010.
